item.title: 2020 Presidential Forecast
item.description: 2020 FORECASTS President House NOTE This model relies on GDP forecasts made by the New York branch of the Federal Reserve. On Friday, April 17, the Fed branch revised its estimate of second-quarter GDP growth sharply downwards, causing the model to adjust its structural forecast in favor of Joe Biden, which greatly increased his estimated chances of winning the election. The pandemic and its economic fallout have caused a lot to change very quickly.

item.title: 2020 House Forecast
item.description: 2020 FORECASTS President House What does a chance feel like? Click the button below to randomly simulate a hypothetical election. While the Democrats may be favored to win, there's a lot of variation in how many seats they may gain or lose. Simulate an election How the odds have changed The model works by using economic indicators, structural factors (like whether it is a midterm year, or the party that controls the White House), and national polling data to estimate what the nationwide popular vote (adding up all the votes for each party in all 435 districts) and the seat breakdown will be.

item.title: Polarization and the American Electorate
item.description: It’s hard to watch the steadiness of Donald Trump’s job approval numbers—43% of voters approving and 52% disapproving, for most of the last year—and not be convinced that Americans are deeply polarized: one half watches Fox news, the other half watches MSNBC; one half hates immigrants, the other embraces them; one half thinks climate change is a hoax, the other wants to pass the Green New Deal. Neither half wants their children to marry a member of the other half.

item.title: One Industrial Union Grand?
item.description:
AFL-CIO headquarters, Washington, D.C.

item.description: MathJax.Hub.Config({ messageStyle: "none", CommonHTML: { linebreaks: { automatic: true } }, tex2jax: {inlineMath: [['$','$']]} }); How the odds have changed The model is continuously updated with new polling data and approval ratings. As new information comes in, the odds may shift towards one party or another. Additionally, as we get closer to the election, there is less uncertainty in the result, since there is less time for a large shift in public opinion.
